"On diaspora* it's possible to format your text in status messages, comments and conversations using a simplified mark-up system called Markdown. This page gives an introduction to the codes used to create this formatting.

Heading
# This is an extremely large header
## Half as big as the one above
### Twice the size of normal text

Italics and bold
Italics: *word* or _word_
Bold: **word** or __word__
Bold italics: ***word*** or ___word___

Bulleted list
*, + or - in front of each line you want as part of the list or 1., 2., etc. in front of the list items

Quotation
When you want to quote an extract of an article or another comment, you can conveniently format your text by starting the line or the paragraph by the > character

Horizontal line
To create a horizontal line, use at least three - - -, _ _ _ or * * * on a separate line. Any number above three will do the same thing and spaces between the characters do not matter.

Inline link
[displayed text here](http://link.address.here \"alt text\") The 'alt text' is optional, and is displayed as a tool-tip when the cursor is moved over the link.

External images
![Alt text](http://website.com/image.jpg \"optional title\") The alternative text in the square brackets is displayed if the image cannot be loaded, and the optional title is displayed as a tool-tip when the cursor is moved over the image; both are useful but not essential.

Escape
If you want your message to include a character which is also used in Markdown coding, you can prevent it from being read by Markdown as a formatting code by 'escaping' it. To do this, place a backslash in front of the character. You can, however, type 'diaspora*' or 'D*' without the asterisk becoming a formatting code!

Special characters
You can create the following symbols and other special characters using a combination of characters:
(c) = © ; (r) = ® ; x^2 = x²"
